justification: The authors state: “we used the confidence forced-choice method … after two consecutive perceptual decisions, the observer reports whether they had greater confidence in the first or second decision,” describing it as their operational measure of confidence.
Table 1 lists “Bayesian confidence: posterior probability of being correct,” identifying this posterior-probability calculation as one way researchers quantify perceptual confidence.

measured_by: Distance-From-Criterion (DFC) metric in extended Signal Detection Theory
justification: The article notes that “One common Evidence-Strength metric is the Distance-From-Criterion (DFC) metric typically used in extended Signal Detection Theory (SDT) models of confidence.”
Under Probability metrics, Table 1 specifies “Log-Probability-Ratio: of posterior probability or likelihood,” presented as an implemented measure of confidence.
Table 1 includes “Drift Diffusion: diffusion process state given elapsed time (Kiani et al., 2014)” as an Evidence-Strength metric for modelling and therefore measuring perceptual confidence.
